issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a no-argument messageOnRide() method (returns String) on the Rideable interface and call it without arguments (see UML and the example in Main). However, the solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (takes an int parameter) and implements messageOnRide(int) in Pig and Seal. This parameter mismatch contradicts the UML, the textual specification (which shows messageOnRide() with no parameters and example return value), and the template Main which calls r.messageOnRide() with no argument. This inconsistency will confuse students about the required signature and return value and can prevent compilation when mixing template usage with the provided solution signatures.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signature consistent across all artifacts. Preferred fix: change the solution to match the problem/template by declaring Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters (String messageOnRide()), and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning the expected string "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]". Alternatively (less recommended), update the problem statement and template to require messageOnRide(int speed) and adjust the UML and examples accordingly — but ensure all three artifacts use the same signature.

issues.description: The problem statement / UML and the template expect a no-argument Rideable.messageOnRide() that returns a String (signature: messageOnRide():String). The solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (and Pig/Seal implement messageOnRide(int speed)). This is a signature/name mismatch: students following the problem/template (which call r.messageOnRide() with no argument) will find the solution's interface and implementations incompatible. This creates mapping and compilation confusion (students will not know whether to implement a no-arg or an int-arg version, and the example/template call sites expect the no-arg form).
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem/template by changing the Rideable interface and its implementations to the no-argument signature: String messageOnRide(). Update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() (no int parameter) and return the expected string format "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]". Alternatively, if an int speed is educationally required, update the problem statement and template examples to include and call messageOnRide(int) consistently — but prefer making the solution match the existing UML/spec to avoid student confusion.
